page.title: 11Staploe, Ecology
page.content: The north and west of the parish are ecologically the richest. There are ancient Ash/Field Maple woods at Bushmead (partly replanted 1976), Dukes Spinney (replanted 1982)and Cates Wood. Their flora includes Nettle leaved bell flower, Primrose and Broad leaved Helleborine, birds, woodpeckers (3 species), nuthatch and sparrowhawk (1984) and mammals, muntjac - common, badgers extinct 1970. Wildflower grassland species, confined to roadside verges and small meadows around Bushmead include Sulphur clover, Common spotted orchid, Crested cow wheat and Spiked star of Bethlehem (also Dukes Spinney). Cowslips are still common. Duloe Brook, the richest stream has kingfishers, Caddis larvae and freshwater shrimps. Farm reservoirs sport Grebes and Short-eared owls.
